classifications.note: Coulomb's Law: F = k|q₁q₂|/r², k = 8.99 × 10⁹ N·m²/C², ε₀ = 8.85 × 10⁻¹² C²/N·m², k = 1/(4πε₀), Inverse-square law: doubling distance → force × 1/4, Valid for point charges or spherical symmetry

principles.statement: Coulomb's Law establishes the quantitative relationship for electrostatic forces: Mathematical Form: F = k|q₁q₂|/r²; F = magnitude of electrostatic force; k = electrostatic constant; q₁, q₂ = charges; r = separation distance. Electrostatic Constant: k = 8.99 × 10⁹ N·m²/C²; Related to permittivity of free space: k = 1/(4πε₀); ε₀ = 8.85 × 10⁻¹² C²/N·m²; Fundamental constant of nature. Force Direction: Like charges: repulsive force; Unlike charges: attractive force; Acts along line joining charges; Central force nature. Vector Form: F₁₂ = k(q₁q₂/r²)r̂₁₂; F₁₂ = force on q₁ due to q₂; r̂₁₂ = unit vector from q₂ to q₁; Includes direction information. Point Charge Assumption: Valid for point charges or spherically symmetric distributions; For non-spherical objects, integration required; Good approximation when r >> object size. Inverse-Square Nature: Force ∝ 1/r²; Same form as gravity; Fundamental property of 3D space; Field lines spread over spherical surface. Comparison with Gravity: Both inverse-square laws; Electrostatic: can be attractive or repulsive; Gravity: always attractive; Electrostatic much stronger for elementary particles. Historical Context: Charles-Augustin de Coulomb (1785); Torsion balance experiments; Confirmed inverse-square law; Foundation of electrostatics. Limitations: Valid for stationary charges; Modifications for moving charges (magnetism); Quantum effects at atomic scales; Relativistic corrections at high speeds.
principles.application: Calculate force between point charges. Determine force direction from charge signs. Analyze distance dependence. Compare electrostatic and gravitational forces. Solve for unknown charges or distances. Apply to spherical charge distributions.
principles.example: Calculate force between two electrons 1 cm apart. Determine distance for specific force. Compare electron-proton force with gravitational attraction.
principles.analogy: Like two people on ice - if they have the same 'charge' (both want personal space), they push each other apart, while if they have opposite 'charges' (attracted to each other), they pull together, with the 'force' weakening rapidly as they get farther apart according to an inverse-square relationship

principles.statement: Electrostatic forces are vectors that combine according to specific principles: Vector Characteristics: Force has magnitude and direction; Acts along line joining charges; Direction determined by charge signs; Can be resolved into components. Superposition Principle: Net force on a charge = vector sum of forces from all other charges; F_net = F₁ + F₂ + F₃ + ...; Each pair interaction independent; Fundamental principle of electrostatics. Component Method: Resolve each force into x, y, z components; Sum components separately: F_net,x = ΣF_ix; F_net,y = ΣF_iy; F_net,z = ΣF_iz; Reconstruct magnitude and direction. Symmetry Considerations: Symmetric charge distributions often cancel components; Can reduce 3D problems to 2D or 1D; Simplifies calculations significantly; Important for problem solving. Equilibrium Conditions: Net force on charge = 0; All force components sum to zero; Can solve for unknown charges or positions; Stable and unstable equilibrium possible. Coordinate Systems: Cartesian coordinates most common; Polar coordinates useful for circular symmetry; Choice affects calculation complexity; Origin placement can simplify problems. Problem Solving Strategy: Identify all charge interactions; Calculate individual force magnitudes; Determine force directions; Resolve into components; Vector sum components; Find net force magnitude/direction. Applications: Multiple charge systems; Continuous charge distributions; Molecular bonding forces; Crystal lattice stability; Plasma physics; Particle beam dynamics.
principles.application: Calculate net force on charges in 2D/3D configurations. Apply superposition to multiple charge systems. Use component method for vector addition. Analyze symmetric charge arrangements. Solve equilibrium problems. Determine unknown charges or positions.

principles.analogy: Like multiple people pulling on ropes attached to an object - each person exerts a force in their specific direction (like individual charge forces), and the object moves according to the vector sum of all these pulls (net force), with the exact same result regardless of the order you consider the pulls (superposition)

principles.statement: Coulomb's Law has wide-ranging applications and important comparative aspects: Atomic Scale Applications: Electron-nucleus attraction in atoms; Chemical bonding forces; Ion formation energies; Atomic structure stability; Fundamental for all chemistry. Macroscopic Applications: Static electricity phenomena; Electrostatic precipitators (pollution control); Photocopiers and laser printers; Inkjet printing; Electrostatic separation. Technological Uses: Van de Graaff generators; Cathode ray tubes; Capacitor design; Particle accelerators; Mass spectrometry. Biological Systems: Membrane potentials; Nerve impulse propagation; Protein folding; DNA structure; Cellular processes. Gravitational Comparison: Both inverse-square laws; F_gravity = Gm₁m₂/r²; For protons: F_elec/F_grav ≈ 1.24 × 10³⁶; Electrostatic much stronger at small scales; Gravity dominates at large scales due to neutrality. Measurement Techniques: Torsion balance (Coulomb's method); Electrometers; Modern precision measurements; Verification of inverse-square law; Determination of elementary charge. Macroscopic Neutrality: Most objects electrically neutral; Surface charges can exist; Static electricity from charge imbalance; Rapid neutralization in conductors. Cosmic Applications: Solar wind interactions; Planetary magnetospheres; Interstellar plasma; Cosmic ray deflection; Stellar structure. Limitations and Extensions: Quantum electrodynamics for small scales; Special relativity for high speeds; Quantum field theory complete description; Still accurate for most engineering applications.

summary: Coulomb's Law, F = k|q₁q₂|/r², quantitatively describes the electrostatic force between two point charges, with k = 8.99 × 10⁹ N·m²/C². The force is inversely proportional to the square of the distance between charges and directly proportional to the product of their magnitudes, with direction along the line joining the charges (repulsive for like charges, attractive for unlike charges). Electrostatic forces are vectors that obey the superposition principle, meaning the net force on a charge equals the vector sum of individual forces from all other charges. This vector nature requires component analysis for multi-charge systems and enables equilibrium calculations where net force equals zero. Compared to gravity, electrostatic forces are immensely stronger at atomic scales (∼10³⁶ times for protons) but often cancel in macroscopic objects due to electrical neutrality. Applications span from atomic physics (electron-nucleus interactions) to technology (electrostatic precipitators, photocopiers) and biological systems (membrane potentials), making Coulomb's Law fundamental to understanding electromagnetic phenomena across all scales of physics.
